This report was prepared by Y. Qian, Governance, Finance and Trade Division, East and

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The  Government  of  the  People's  Republic  of  China  (PRC)  requested  the  Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) during the 2003 country programming mission to provide technical 
assistance (TA) for Strengthening the Statistical System of the China Banking Regulatory 
Commission (CBRC). In response to the request, a fact-finding mission1 visited Beijing on 
15- 20  April  2004.  The  mission  met  with  officials  from  CBRC  and  relevant  government 
agencies, and agreed on the TA objectives, scope, and implementation arrangements. The 
TA logical framework is in Appendix 1.  
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  CBRC was established in April 2003  as part of the restructuring of the financial 
supervisory  framework  to  strengthen  banking  supervision  and  reorient  the  focus  of  the 
People’s Bank of China (PBC) as the  central bank.2 This step was taken to draw a line 
between banking supervision and monetary policy, and to strengthen banking supervision 
capacities. CBRC’s creation also finalizes the transfer of PBC’s formerly all-encompassing 
regulatory powers over the financial service industry.3 CBRC’s main responsibilities are to (i) 
issue regulations and  guidelines related to banking organizations and nonbank financial 
institutions  (NBFIs)  subject  to  CBRC’s  supervision;  (ii)  examine  and  approve  the 
establishment, closure, and modification of banking organizations and NBFIs, their branches, 
and their scope of business;  and (iii) conduct on-site and off-site supervision of banking 
organizations and NBFIs. 
 
3.  The legal basis for the separation of CBRC from PBC, and for CBRC’s function 
derives from the three banking laws that took effect in February 2004.4 The Central Bank Law 
solidifies the position of PBC as legally responsible for determining and executing monetary 
policy, managing the foreign exchange market, guarding against financial risk, ensuring 
financial stability, and combating money laundering. The Banking Supervision Law mandates 
CBRC to regulate and supervise all banks, other depository institutions, and NBFIs. This law 
introduced  some  of  the  Basel  Core  Principles  for  Effective  Banking  Supervision  and 
international norms or standards for banking supervision.  Adoption of these principles is 
designed to steer commercial banks toward better risk control. The Commercial Banking Law 
removes from the state-owned commercial banks (SOCBs) the obligation to grant loans to 
projects approved by the State Council. The law  also allows banks to  participate in many 
activities taken for granted in advanced economies: purchasing and selling government and 
financial bonds, engaging in foreign exchange, and offering bank card services.5 
 
4.  Four  SOCBs—Industrial  and  Commercial  Bank  of  China,  Bank  of  China,  China 
Construction Bank, and Agricultural Bank of China—account for about two thirds of market

5  Although banks are  prohibited from  investing in NBFIs, the laws leave room for  expanding into nonbank

2    
share in terms of total assets. The country has 11 joint-stock commercial banks (JSCBs) with 
a little more than 10% market share, over 3,000 rural credit cooperatives (RCCs) with 10% 
market share, and more than 100 city commercial banks with about 5% market share. The 
market share of foreign banking organizations is still small, at only 1.4%. 
 
5.  An  effective  financial  statistical  system  is  indispensable  for  macroeconomic 
management and financial sector supervision. To a certain degree, the PRC has established 
a  statistical  system  for  monetary  policy  management  and  international  exchange  of 
information, including with the International Monetary Fund’s International Financial Statistics, 
on financial market stability and interbank markets. However, when PBC was the banking 
supervisor it did not establish a comprehensive statistical system for CBRC supervisory 
needs in general, or off-site surveillance with early-warning features in particular. Commercial 
banks still prepare statistical tables without direct relevance to supervision.6 
 
6.  The  statistical  system  for  banking  supervision  lacks  a  systematic  and  integral 
approach. This is reflected by the following:  
 
(i)  Banking supervisory statistics are not comprehensively designed. Statistical 
indicators  do  not  adequately  reflect  banking  risks,  nor  do  they  meet 
supervisory requirements. 
(ii)  Given  the  compartmental  structure,  many  PBC  and  CBRC  departments 
repeatedly  request  similar  information  from  financial  institutions.  However, 
these information requests are not consistent with each other and are not 
shared and used across PBC and CBRC departments. Data on RCCs and 
urban credit cooperatives are not reported to the headquarters of PBC and 
CBRC. 
(iii)  Commercial banks submit limited ad hoc information by branch or functional 
department to their corresponding supervisory departments within the former 
PBC  or  CBRC  branches.  Coherent  and  consolidated  data  are  difficult  to 
acquire. Information on operational aspects and risk assessment, which is 
valuable for supervisors, was not systematically collected. 
(iv)  Most information is on paper or diskette. A comprehensive database to allow 
quick inquiry and information sharing does not exist. 
(v)  Banking supervisors, security market and insurance market supervisors, and 
other  financial  market  policymakers  have  no  mechanism  for  information 
sharing.  
 
7.  The 1997 Asian financial crisis was exacerbated partly by a lack of timely, frequent, 
easily accessible, and sufficiently disaggregated statistical information. The availability of 
such statistics and a key set of crisis-monitoring indicators could significantly reduce the 
vulnerability of financial markets and, thereby, the risk of crisis. The advances in accounting 
rules7 and adoption of internal risk ratings8 by commercial banks will require the supervisory 
authority to adopt a more prudent statistical system. PRC banks will not implement the new 
Basel II minimum capital requirement immediately and will stay with the Basel I accord. As 
part of the fundamental change in the supervisory principle, from regulatory compliance to 
risk-based supervision, CBRC has embraced the second and third pillar of Basel II. These

was designed in the 1950s when PBC was the sole bank owned by the Government and performed treasury 
functions. 
7  The Ministry of Finance issued the Accounting Principles for Finance Enterprises in 2001.

3  
measures include regulatory supervision and market discipline through disclosure, as well as 
the Core Principles of Effective Banking Supervision. Successful implementation of these 
accords and principles will require an efficient and effective statistical system that produces 
accurate and timely data. 
 
8.  CBRC has given high priority to establishing the new statistical system. The first 
CBRC meeting on the statistical system was held in September 2003, and a policy decision 
was made to establish a risk-based supervision statistical system to comprehensively reflect 
the credit, market, liquidity, and operational risks of commercial banks. The new statistical 
system will meet international standards and be based on consolidated financial institution 
data. Static and dynamic statistical indicators will be collected to reflect commercial bank 
operations in local and foreign currency, and on- and off-balance-sheet activities. The new 
statistical system should be able to meet the needs of supervisory authorities for off- and on-
site inspection, risk assessment, early warning, and information disclosure.  
 
9.  CBRC has 15 departments. Banking Supervision Department I is responsible for 
supervision of SOCBs and asset management companies; Banking Supervision Department 
II for JSCBs and city commercial banks; and Banking Supervision Department III for policy 
banks, postal savings institutions, and foreign banking organizations. The Nonbank Financial 
Institution  Supervision  Department  is  responsible  for  NBFIs;9  Cooperative  Finance 
Supervision Department for supervising rural and urban credit cooperatives; and Statistical 
Department for coordinating with line supervisory departments in supervisory data collection, 
analysis, and information management. CBRC’s Information Center is mandated to develop 
an integrated information system for CBRC. 
 
10.  Asian Development Bank's Operations and Strategy. One of the objectives of 
ADB’s PRC country operational strategy is to support the Government’s efforts to reform the 
financial sector by strengthening CBRC’s capability in prudential supervision and to facilitate 
complete  integration  of  the  financial  sector  into  the  global  financial  market.  ADB  has 
supported strengthening banking supervisors’ institutional capability through TAs.10 The first 
two were completed successfully, helped formulate a liquidity risk management model for the 
PBC Shanghai branch, helped draft the recently adopted banking laws, and proposed further 
legal reforms in the banking sector. The third TA is being implemented. 
 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Purpose and Output 
11.  The TA purpose is to strengthen the institutional capacities of CBRC as the banking 
regulator by establishing a statistics system that is consistent with  risk-based supervision 
principles and meets the needs of supervisory authorities for off-site surveillance and on-site 
inspection, risk assessment, early warning, and information disclosure. 
 
                                                 
9  Excluding those conducting securities, futures, and insurance businesses. 
10 ADB. 1998. Technical Assistance to the People’s Republic of China for Strengthening Banking Supervision and 
Liquidity Risk Management. Manila; ADB. 2002. Technical Assistance to the People’s Republic of China for 
Banking Laws and Regulations. Manila; and ADB. 2003. Technical Assistance to the People’s Republic of China 
for Foreign Bank Rating and Risk Control System. Manila.

4    
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
12.  The scope of the TA includes the following: 
 
(i)  Design statistical indicators, data submission criteria, and reporting formats for 
the statistical system, which will cover information in accounting, credit risk, 
market risk, liquidity risk, capital and reserves, other banking business, and 
external information. 
 
(ii)  Prepare  instruction  books  and  conduct  training  activities  for  banking 
supervisors  and  commercial  banks  to  understand  the  structural  and 
operational aspects of the new statistical system. 
 
(iii)  Recommend a prudent analytical framework for risk-based supervision based 
on new statistical information. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
13.  The total TA cost is estimated at $600,000 equivalent, comprising $275,000 in foreign 
exchange costs and $325,000 equivalent in local currency costs. It is proposed that ADB 
finance $400,000 equivalent, consisting of the entire foreign exchange costs and $125,000 
equivalent in local costs. The TA will be financed on a grant basis by ADB's TA funding 
program. The Government will contribute $200,000 in kind for office space, counterpart staff, 
transportation, and other services. Details of the cost estimate are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
14.  CBRC’s Statistical Department will be the Executing Agency. A leading group will be 
set up comprising senior management of CBRC and commercial banks. The director general 
of the Statistical Department will be the secretary of the leading group. A working group will 
be set up, led by the director general and comprising technical representatives from CBRC 
supervisory departments and commercial banks. The working group will be the consultants’ 
counterparts,  regularly  exchange  information  with  the  PBC  counterparts  regarding  TA 
implementation progress, and ensure that the TA will contribute to PBC’s and CBRC’s joint 
effort  to  monitor  financial  crises  and  stabilize  the  financial  market.  CBRC’s  Statistical 
Department will provide office space, counterpart staff, transportation, and other services to 
the consultants, and will arrange meetings for them with agencies and organizations. A 
limited number of senior CBRC statistics experts will train in countries with advanced risk-
based supervision statistics systems. CBRC staff members will also seek internships to gain 
experience working side by side with foreign counterparts. 
 
15.  The TA will engage two international consultants for a total of 7 person-months, 
including a supervisory statistical system specialist (4 person-months) and an accounting and 
statistics specialist (3 person-months), and two domestic consultants for a total of 8 person-
months, including a supervisory statistical system specialist (4 person-months) and banking 
operation  and  training  specialist  (4  person-months).  The  budget  provides  for  engaging 
resource persons for specific technical areas. The terms of reference for consultants are in 
Appendix  3.  The  consultants  will  be  selected  and  engaged  on  an  individual  basis  in 
accordance with ADB’s  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of  Consultants  and  other  arrangements 
satisfactory  to  ADB  for  the  engagement  of  domestic  consultants.  Equipment  (notebook 
computers, fax machines, scanners, data storage devices, and photocopiers) will be procured

5  
by EA in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines for Procurement. The advance payment facility 
procedure  will  be  adopted  to  facilitate  timely  organization  of  training,  seminars,  and 
conference activities. 
 
16.  The consultants will submit (i) inception reports 2 weeks after their services start, (ii) 
progress reports at appropriate stages of TA implementation, (iii) a draft final report before 
the conclusion of the contract, and (iv) a final report two weeks after incorporating EA and 
ADB's  comments.  All  reports  will  be  submitted  in  English  and  Chinese.  The  TA  will 
commence in August 2004 and be completed in June 2005. Workshops will be organized 
periodically to invite comments from international and domestic experts and to disseminate 
the findings of the report.  
 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
17.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $400,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of the People’s Republic of China for Strengthening of the Statistical System 
of the China Banking Regulatory Commission, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  International Consultants (7 person-months)  
 
1.  Team Leader and  Supervisory Statistical System Specialist (4 person-
months) 
 
1.  As the team leader, the consultant will be responsible for overall technical assistance 
(TA) implementation, timely delivery of all reports, recruitment, and management of resource 
persons for various technical tasks, and organization of conferences and training. As the 
supervisory statistical system specialist, the consultant  will lead in establishing the new 
supervisory statistical system and associated operational mechanisms for its most efficient 
use. The specialist will possess deep knowledge of the People’s Republic of China (PRC) 
financial sector and sufficient experience in banking supervision and statistics in countries 
with advanced banking markets. Specifically the consultant will do the following: 
 
(i)  Identify weaknesses in the existing supervisory statistical system and areas 
that it needs to address to be consistent with the movement of the China 
Banking  Regulatory  Commission  (CBRC)  toward  risk-based  banking 
supervision. 
(ii)  Establish  objectives  of  statistical  support  for  various  supervision  activities 
(based  on  the  Basel  Principles  on  Effective  Supervision)  for  off-site 
surveillance and on-site supervision, data analysis, categorization, disclosure, 
and decision making on regulatory actions and enforcement, and elaborate 
how the new statistical system can better support each activity. 
(iii)  Introduce  the  experience  of  countries  with  advanced  banking  markets  in 
design and implementation of supervisory statistical systems. 
(iv)  Recommend a strategy to combine best international experience with the PRC 
banking industry in terms of statistical indicator design and the mechanism for 
efficient operation of the statistical system. 
(v)  Design a set of statistical indicators for the new supervisory statistical system, 
including detailed formulas, economic definitions, and data sources for each 
indicator to provide supervisory information in the following areas: 
 
(a)  accounting, (e.g., balance sheet, income and cash-flow statements, 
etc.); 
(b)  credit risks (e.g., loan aging and risk rating, concentration, connected 
lending, sector and regional breakdowns, etc.); 
(c)  market risks (e.g., interest rates, exchanges rates, etc.); 
(d)  liquidity risks (e.g., maturity mismatches, loan-deposit ratio, ratio of 
liquid to total assets, etc.);  
(e)  reserves  (e.g.,  tier-I  capital,  tier-II  capital,  general  reserve,  special 
reserves, etc.); and  
(f)  other  banking  business  and  external  information  (e.g.,  fee-based 
income, large transactions, human resources, etc.).

local CBRC and People’s Bank of China offices, identify needed changes for 
consolidated  reporting,  recommend  implementation  strategies  for  the  new 
procedures  at  the  commercial  bank  level,  and  ensure  that  the

(vii)  Design  data  submission  criteria,  frequency,  and  reporting  formats,  which

commercial banks. 
(viii)  Recommend  the  division  of  labor  for  information  gathering  among  CBRC 
headquarters, CBRC local branches, and commercial banks. 
(ix)  Recommend a prudent analytic framework for risk-based supervision based on 
the  new  statistical  information  and  how  to  use  the  analytical  results  in

(x)  Help draft new internal operational guidelines and procedures for  statistics 
collection, analysis, and disclosure, and improve existing ones. 
(xi)  Lead the preparation of policy and instruction books for banking supervisors 
and commercial banks to understand the structural and operational aspects of 
the new statistical system. 
(xii)  Recommend a strategy and organize conferences and training activities to

(xiii)  Examine the legal and regulatory framework, identify inconsistencies with the

(xiv)  Identify  key  issues  for  information  system  development  to  support  the

as a starting point for CBRC to move to the next stage of integrating the

2.  Accounting and Statistics Specialist (3 person-months) 
 
2.  In consultation with the supervisory statistical system specialist, the consultant will 
take the lead in tasks relating to integration of commercial bank financial reporting with 
supervisory reporting, and provide advisory services to the EA on specific accounting issues 
of commercial banks.  The specialist will possess sufficient experience in accounting and 
auditing practices in the PRC financial sector, and have sufficient exposure in this area in 
developed countries with advanced banking industries. Specifically the consultant will do the 
following: 
 
(i)  Examine  how  existing  accounting  and  audit  rules  and  standards  affect 
commercial banks’ operations, and how accounting rules are inconsistent with 
commercial banks’ financial management policies. 
(ii)  Evaluate  accounting  rules  on  the  reserve  policy  of  commercial  banks, 
specifically  regarding  the  general  reserve,  and  special  reserves  for 
nonperforming loans and for writing them off.

(vi)  Examine financial reporting issues at the commercial bank branch level and at

(vii)  Coordinate with the supervisory statistical system specialist in designing data

recommend ways to ease compliance by commercial banks. 
(viii)  Evaluate the financial management policies of commercial banks against the 
need  for  prudent  banking  and  regulatory  compliance,  and  recommend 
measures for improvement, internally and externally (e.g., recommendation of 
new accounting rules for Ministry of Finance to consider). 
 
B.  Domestic Consultants (8 person-months) 
 
18.  Domestic consultants will have extensive in-depth country and sector knowledge and 
good contacts with the Government and financial institutions. The domestic consultants will 
help the international consultants quickly become familiar with their tasks by translating 
various  documents  into  English;  researching  and  compiling  key  government  policies, 
regulations,  and  procedures;  and  ensuring  that  the  international  consultants’  output  is 
appropriate for the PRC. The domestic consultants will possess sufficient experience in their 
fields, and will include the following: 
 
(i)  The supervisory statistical system specialist (4 person-months) will help 
the international consultant team leader in the  overall management of TA 
implementation, timely delivery of good-quality interim and final reports, and 
recruitment and management of resource persons in various technical tasks. 
The consultant will also help the international consultants  
  
(a)  identify weaknesses in the supervisory statistical system, and the areas 
that  it  needs  to  address;  and  the  policy,  institutional,  legal,  and 
regulatory impediments to the operation of the new system; 
(b)  design a set of statistical indicators for the new supervisory statistical 
system,  including  detailed  definition,  data  source,  and  economic 
definition for each indicator; 
(c)  design data submission criteria, submission frequency and reporting 
formats, considering the need to synchronize existing procedures at 
CBRC and commercial banks; 
(d)  adopt the new procedures at commercial banks, and ensure that the 
recommendations  are  practical  from  their  perspective  and  that  the 
reporting burden is not onerous;

(f)  prepare  policy  and  instruction  books  for  banking  supervisors  and

(g)  assess CBRC’s capacity to manage the new statistical system, design

(ii)  The banking operation and training specialist (4 person-months) will help 
the international consultants 
 
(a)  conduct a training needs assessment for CBRC senior management, 
supervisory departments, commercial bank senior management, and 
technical personnel regarding the new supervisory statistical system; 
(b)  evaluate training mechanisms within CBRC, and among CBRC and 
commercial  banks,  and  identify  the  best  mechanisms  to  conduct 
training activities; 
(c)  help prepare policy and instruction books for banking supervisors and 
commercial banks to understand the structural and operational aspects 
of  the  new  statistical  system  and  organize  corresponding  training 
activities; and 
(d)  help  the  international  supervisory  statistical  system  specialist 
consultant organize and conduct conferences and training sessions on 
the formulation and implementation of the new supervisory system.
